articles.headline: Recession Elsewhere, but It’s Booming in China
articles.snippet: Aggressive bank lending is sending Chinese consumers on a shopping spree, while Americans spend more prudently.
articles.abstract: Aggressive bank lending is sending Chinese consumers on a shopping spree, while Americans spend more prudently.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China  For the first time, Chinese will buy more cars this year than Americans. Demand is so high that drivers put their names on long waiting lists for the most popular models.

articles.headline: Not Yet the Season for a Nook
articles.snippet: Every one of the Nook’s vaunted distinctions from Amazon’s Kindle comes fraught with disappointing footnotes.
articles.abstract: Every one of the Nook’s vaunted distinctions from Amazon’s Kindle comes fraught with disappointing footnotes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The holidays are no joyride. Between the stress, the money and the relatives, no wonder so many people contract Seasonal Depression, Financial-Obligation Migraine and Family Drama Disorder.

articles.headline: For Elderly in Rural Areas, Times Are Distinctly Harder
articles.snippet: The recession and cuts to programs for aging Americans have made growing old in isolated areas even tougher.
articles.abstract: The recession and cuts to programs for aging Americans have made growing old in isolated areas even tougher.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINGLE, Wyo.  Norma Clark, 80, slipped on the ice out by the horse corral one afternoon and broke her hip in four places. Alone, it took her three hours to drag herself the 40 yards back to the house through snow and mud, after she had tied her legs together with rope to stabilize the injury.

articles.headline: China’s Economic Power Unsettles the Neighbors
articles.snippet: China is finding it harder to cast itself as a friendly alternative to an imperious American superpower.
articles.abstract: China is finding it harder to cast itself as a friendly alternative to an imperious American superpower.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASARKEMIS, Indonesia — In the Dickensian depths of the Dunia Metal Works here, all is cacophony: the bam bam bam of grease-drenched punches; the rhythmic clank of unspooling steel wire; the storm and stress of glinting, freshly minted nails cascading onto a broad metal table for boxing.

articles.headline: Citi Is Eager to Pay Back Bailout Aid
articles.snippet: Persuading the government that it can stand on its own would be a milestone in the nation’s financial recovery. But it is not clear that Citi will be able to do so.
articles.abstract: Persuading the government that it can stand on its own would be a milestone in the nation’s financial recovery. But it is not clear that Citi will be able to do so.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after accepting two taxpayer bailouts, Citigroup is racing to raise billions of dollars in the stock market to repay the aid, a crucial step in freeing itself from Washington’s grip.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Units Omit Name and Excel
articles.snippet: A.I.G. is once again the top seller of fixed annuities to bank customers, although the contracts are being offered under the names of two subsidiaries.
articles.abstract: A.I.G. is once again the top seller of fixed annuities to bank customers, although the contracts are being offered under the names of two subsidiaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just months after dropping the telltale “A.I.G.” from its sales brochures, the company has leapfrogged its competitors and reclaimed a title it held for many years before its bailout  the top seller of fixed annuities to bank customers.

articles.headline: Britain to Levy a One-Time Tax on Banker Bonuses
articles.snippet: A tax seen as the most direct attack on bank bonuses in the world is part of Britain’s effort to shore up its finances.
articles.abstract: A tax seen as the most direct attack on bank bonuses in the world is part of Britain’s effort to shore up its finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: As bankers revel over the return of big Wall Street paydays, the unthinkable is happening in Britain, where the government is making the most direct attack on bank bonuses anywhere in the world.

articles.headline: A Testy Exchange at White House Over Jobs Proposals
articles.snippet: President Obama and Congressional Republican leaders met on Wednesday to discuss how to create more jobs and air philosophical differences on stimulus measures.
articles.abstract: President Obama and Congressional Republican leaders met on Wednesday to discuss how to create more jobs and air philosophical differences on stimulus measures.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As diplomats might say of a meeting between rivals that is just short of undiplomatic, President Obama and Congressional Republican leaders had a full and frank discussion at the White House on Wednesday when they met to discuss how to create more jobs.

articles.headline: Pakistan Detains Five Americans in Raid Tied to Militants
articles.snippet: Five young Muslim American men who had disappeared were detained in Pakistan in a raid linked to a militant group.
articles.abstract: Five young Muslim American men who had disappeared were detained in Pakistan in a raid linked to a militant group.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Five young Muslim American men from the Washington suburbs who disappeared late last month were detained in Pakistan on Wednesday in a police raid on a house linked to a militant group, American and Pakistani officials said.
